name: Kay Ivey
bio: Kay Ivey is the 54th Governor of Alabama, serving since 2017. She previously served as State Treasurer and Lieutenant Governor, becoming the first Republican woman elected to both offices in Alabama history.
education: Auburn University (BA in Secondary Education, 1967)
endorsements: Alabama Farmers Federation, National Rifle Association, Alabama Forestry Association
platform: Workforce development, broadband expansion, education reform, and infrastructure investment.

platformFollowThrough.Workforce Development: Signed the Alabama Workforce Transformation Act (2024), replacing the Department of Labor with the Department of Workforce. Led the 'Working for Alabama' legislative package to boost labor participation and rural job growth.
platformFollowThrough.Broadband Expansion: Awarded over $190 million in broadband grants since 2024, laying 2,347 miles of fiber across 23 counties. Delivered high-speed internet to more than 15,000 households and businesses.
platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Signed the Alabama Literacy Act (2019) and Numeracy Act (2022). Launched the CHOOSE Act (2025) to expand school choice and issued executive orders for statewide literacy and teacher apprenticeships.
platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Investment: Signed the Powering Growth Plan (2025) to expand energy infrastructure and create the Alabama Energy Infrastructure Bank.

proposals: Expand dual enrollment programs, increase rural broadband access, and improve prison infrastructure.
vetoes: Rarely uses veto power; most legislation is signed or allowed to pass without signature.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Mike Dunleavy
bio: Mike Dunleavy is the 12th Governor of Alaska, serving since 2018. A former educator and state senator, he has focused his administration on fiscal reform, resource development, and public safety.
education: Misericordia University (BA), University of Alaska Fairbanks (MEd)
endorsements: Alaska Republican Party, National Rifle Association, Alaska Miners Association
platform: Fiscal responsibility, resource development, crime reduction, and education reform.

platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Responsibility: Vetoed SB113 (2025), a corporate tax reform bill, citing the need for a broader fiscal plan with spending limits and competitive investment policies.
platformFollowThrough.Resource Development: Advanced infrastructure permitting agreements with federal agencies to streamline energy and mining projects.
platformFollowThrough.Crime Reduction: Continued support for rural law enforcement expansion and public safety initiatives.
platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Backed charter school expansion and alternatives to traditional schooling in his 2025 State of the State address.

proposals: Comprehensive fiscal reform, expanded charter school authorization, and long-term energy infrastructure development.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Nikolao Pula
bio: Nikolao Pula is the 9th Governor of American Samoa, elected in 2024 and inaugurated in 2025. He previously served nearly three decades in the U.S. Department of the Interior’s Office of Insular Affairs, including as Director from 2002 to 2022. He is the first Republican Governor of American Samoa since 1993.
education: Menlo College, Brigham Young University, George Mason University
endorsements: American Samoa Republican Party, local church coalitions, Pacific Islander civic groups
platform: Government transparency, education reform, infrastructure modernization, and economic development.

platformFollowThrough.Government Transparency: Announced plans for a public-facing budget dashboard and quarterly departmental audits.
platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Proposed vocational training expansion and partnerships with U.S. institutions for remote learning.
platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Modernization: Outlined upgrades to Pago Pago Harbor and rural road networks.
platformFollowThrough.Economic Development: Introduced tax incentives for small businesses and expanded tourism outreach.

proposals: Create a territorial innovation hub, expand healthcare access, and modernize emergency response systems.
vetoes: No vetoes issued or documented as of October 2025.
rankingNote: Not enough official data to rank or score. Polling and engagement metrics unavailable.

name: Katie Hobbs
bio: Katie Hobbs is the 24th Governor of Arizona, elected in 2022. She previously served as Arizona’s Secretary of State and as a member of the state legislature. Her administration focuses on education, water security, and reproductive rights.
education: Northern Arizona University (BSW), Arizona State University (MSW)
endorsements: Planned Parenthood, Arizona Education Association, Emily’s List
platform: Public education investment, water conservation, reproductive rights, and affordable housing.

platformFollowThrough.Public Education Investment: Proposed a $1.3 billion education budget for 2024, including teacher pay raises and school infrastructure upgrades.
platformFollowThrough.Water Conservation: Launched the Arizona Water Resilience Initiative to secure long-term water access and reduce overuse.
platformFollowThrough.Reproductive Rights: Issued executive orders protecting abortion access and blocked enforcement of outdated territorial-era bans.
platformFollowThrough.Affordable Housing: Expanded state housing grants and partnered with municipalities to increase low-income housing development.

proposals: Universal pre-K, statewide drought mitigation plan, and expanded mental health services.
vetoes: Vetoed SB1231 (2023), which would have restricted gender-affirming care for minors.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Sarah Huckabee Sanders
bio: Sarah Huckabee Sanders is the 47th Governor of Arkansas, elected in 2022. She previously served as White House Press Secretary and is the daughter of former Governor Mike Huckabee. Her administration emphasizes education reform, public safety, and conservative values.
education: Ouachita Baptist University (BA in Political Science, 2004)
endorsements: Arkansas Republican Party, National Rifle Association, Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America
platform: Education overhaul, crime prevention, tax cuts, and parental rights.

platformFollowThrough.Education Overhaul: Signed the LEARNS Act (2023), restructuring Arkansas’s education system with school choice, literacy benchmarks, and teacher pay increases.
platformFollowThrough.Crime Prevention: Increased funding for law enforcement and launched initiatives targeting violent crime and drug trafficking.
platformFollowThrough.Tax Cuts: Reduced individual income tax rates and proposed further cuts to corporate taxes.
platformFollowThrough.Parental Rights: Issued executive orders reinforcing parental control over education and healthcare decisions.

proposals: Expand school voucher programs, eliminate state income tax, and strengthen border security partnerships.
vetoes: Vetoed HB1782 (2024), which proposed expanded gambling operations, citing moral and economic concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Gavin Newsom
bio: Gavin Newsom is the 40th Governor of California, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. He previously served as Lieutenant Governor and Mayor of San Francisco. His administration focuses on climate action, housing, healthcare, and progressive reform.
education: Santa Clara University (BA in Political Science, 1989)
endorsements: California Democratic Party, Sierra Club, SEIU California
platform: Climate leadership, universal healthcare, housing affordability, and criminal justice reform.

platformFollowThrough.Climate Leadership: Advanced California’s carbon neutrality goals, banned new oil drilling near communities, and expanded electric vehicle incentives.
platformFollowThrough.Universal Healthcare: Expanded Medi-Cal eligibility and launched CalAIM to integrate behavioral health and social services.
platformFollowThrough.Housing Affordability: Streamlined housing permits, invested in Project Homekey, and signed laws to increase density near transit.
platformFollowThrough.Criminal Justice Reform: Ended cash bail for nonviolent offenses and expanded reentry programs for formerly incarcerated individuals.

proposals: Implement single-payer healthcare, accelerate offshore wind development, and expand mental health courts.
vetoes: Vetoed AB1228 (2023), which proposed expanded labor protections for fast food workers, citing cost concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Jared Polis
bio: Jared Polis is the 43rd Governor of Colorado, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. He previously served in the U.S. House of Representatives and is known for his work in education, renewable energy, and healthcare reform.
education: Princeton University (BA in Politics, 1996)
endorsements: Colorado Democratic Party, Sierra Club, Equality Colorado
platform: Universal preschool, clean energy transition, healthcare affordability, and criminal justice reform.

platformFollowThrough.Universal Preschool: Launched Colorado’s free universal preschool program in 2023, serving over 40,000 children statewide.
platformFollowThrough.Clean Energy Transition: Advanced Colorado’s goal of 100% renewable electricity by 2040 and expanded electric vehicle infrastructure.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Affordability: Implemented the Colorado Option to reduce insurance premiums and expand coverage.
platformFollowThrough.Criminal Justice Reform: Signed legislation to end cash bail for low-level offenses and expand police accountability measures.

proposals: Expand mental health services, accelerate wildfire mitigation, and increase affordable housing supply.
vetoes: Vetoed SB98 (2024), which proposed restrictions on local zoning reform, citing housing affordability concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Ned Lamont
bio: Ned Lamont is the 89th Governor of Connecticut, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. A businessman and educator, Lamont has focused his administration on fiscal stability, infrastructure modernization, and education reform.
education: Harvard College (BA), Yale School of Management (MBA)
endorsements: Connecticut Democratic Party, Connecticut Education Association, Sierra Club Connecticut
platform: Transportation upgrades, fiscal reform, education investment, and public health expansion.

platformFollowThrough.Transportation Upgrades: Advanced the CT2030 infrastructure plan, investing in rail, highways, and public transit modernization.
platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Reform: Delivered balanced budgets with record Rainy Day Fund levels and credit rating upgrades.
platformFollowThrough.Education Investment: Expanded early childhood education and increased funding for public schools and workforce training.
platformFollowThrough.Public Health Expansion: Strengthened mental health services and launched initiatives to combat opioid addiction.

proposals: Expand affordable housing, accelerate green energy adoption, and improve access to behavioral health care.
vetoes: Vetoed HB6782 (2024), which proposed changes to municipal zoning laws, citing concerns over local control.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Matt Meyer
bio: Matt Meyer is the 76th Governor of Delaware, elected in 2024. He previously served as New Castle County Executive from 2017 to 2025 and worked as an attorney, diplomat, and entrepreneur. His administration focuses on education, healthcare, housing, and sustainability.
education: Brown University (BA), University of Michigan (JD)
endorsements: Delaware Democratic Party, Delaware State Education Association, Sierra Club Delaware
platform: Education reform, healthcare access, affordable housing, and climate resilience.

platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Proposed teacher salary increases, curriculum modernization, and statewide literacy initiatives.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Access: Announced plans to expand Medicaid and establish Delaware’s first medical school.
platformFollowThrough.Affordable Housing: Backed zoning reform and housing supply expansion for marginalized communities.
platformFollowThrough.Climate Resilience: Set goal for net-zero emissions in state operations by 2030 and expanded renewable energy investment.

proposals: Launch a state-managed health plan, boost clean energy jobs, and expand mental health services.
vetoes: No vetoes issued or documented as of October 2025.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Ron DeSantis
bio: Ron DeSantis is the 46th Governor of Florida, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. A former Navy officer and U.S. Congressman, DeSantis has focused his administration on education reform, tax policy, and conservative governance.
education: Yale University (BA), Harvard Law School (JD)
endorsements: Florida Republican Party, Club for Growth, National Rifle Association
platform: Education reform, tax reduction, immigration enforcement, and parental rights.

platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Expanded school choice, banned certain curriculum content, and increased teacher pay.
platformFollowThrough.Tax Reduction: Proposed elimination of property taxes and signed multiple sales tax holidays.
platformFollowThrough.Immigration Enforcement: Signed legislation mandating E-Verify and restricting undocumented access to state services.
platformFollowThrough.Parental Rights: Enacted laws limiting school content and increasing parental control over education.

proposals: Fully eliminate property taxes, expand charter school funding, and restrict ESG investment practices.
vetoes: Vetoed HB991 (2024), which would have expanded defamation liability for media outlets.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Brian Kemp
bio: Brian Kemp is the 83rd Governor of Georgia, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. A former Secretary of State and small business owner, Kemp has focused his administration on economic development, public safety, and conservative governance.
education: University of Georgia (BA in Agriculture)
endorsements: Georgia Republican Party, National Federation of Independent Business, Georgia Chamber of Commerce
platform: Economic growth, public safety, education reform, and election integrity.

platformFollowThrough.Economic Growth: Georgia ranked No. 1 for business for 12 consecutive years, with record-breaking job creation and investment.
platformFollowThrough.Public Safety: Increased funding for law enforcement and signed anti-gang legislation.
platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Expanded school choice and literacy programs.
platformFollowThrough.Election Integrity: Signed SB202 to overhaul Georgia’s voting laws, including ID requirements and ballot access changes.

proposals: Further expand vocational training, reduce income tax rates, and strengthen border enforcement partnerships.
vetoes: Vetoed HB404 (2023), a housing reform bill, citing concerns over property rights and regulatory overreach.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Lou Leon Guerrero
bio: Lou Leon Guerrero is the 9th Governor of Guam and the first woman to hold the office. A former nurse, legislator, and banking executive, she has focused her administration on fiscal recovery, healthcare access, and infrastructure investment.
education: California State University, Los Angeles (BS), UCLA (MPH), University of Washington (GrDip)
endorsements: Democratic Party of Guam, Guam Nurses Association, Bank of Guam Board
platform: Fiscal stability, healthcare expansion, infrastructure upgrades, and workforce development.

platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Stability: Delivered six consecutive years of budget surpluses and eliminated borrowing for operating costs.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Expansion: Invested in Medicaid access and proposed exempting Medicaid-related revenue from business taxes.
platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Upgrades: Deployed $100M in ARP funds for power and water infrastructure in Mangilao.
platformFollowThrough.Workforce Development: Raised wages for teachers, nurses, law enforcement, and social workers.

proposals: Expand childcare assistance, increase rental aid, and raise the Business Privilege Tax cap for small businesses.
vetoes: No vetoes documented as of October 2025.
rankingNote: Not ranked—no verified polling available. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Joshua Green
bio: Joshua Green is the 9th Governor of Hawaii, elected in 2022. A physician and former Lieutenant Governor, Green has focused his administration on housing, healthcare, climate resilience, and disaster recovery.
education: Swarthmore College (BA), Penn State College of Medicine (MD)
endorsements: Hawaii Democratic Party, Hawaii Medical Association, Sierra Club Hawaii
platform: Affordable housing, healthcare access, climate action, and emergency preparedness.

platformFollowThrough.Affordable Housing: Launched the $1 billion Affordable Hawaii Housing Fund to accelerate development and reduce homelessness.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Access: Expanded Medicaid coverage and rural health services.
platformFollowThrough.Climate Action: Advanced carbon neutrality goals and invested in shoreline protection.
platformFollowThrough.Emergency Preparedness: Led wildfire recovery efforts in Maui and expanded disaster response infrastructure.

proposals: Create a statewide mental health corps, expand renewable energy jobs, and increase teacher housing stipends.
vetoes: Vetoed HB998 (2025), which proposed changes to shoreline setback rules, citing environmental risks.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Brad Little
bio: Brad Little is the 33rd Governor of Idaho, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. A rancher and former Lieutenant Governor, Little has focused his administration on tax relief, education investment, and conservative governance.
education: University of Idaho (BA in Agribusiness)
endorsements: Idaho Republican Party, Idaho Farm Bureau, National Rifle Association
platform: Tax cuts, education funding, regulatory rollback, and rural development.

platformFollowThrough.Tax Cuts: Signed legislation delivering over $1 billion in tax relief since 2019.
platformFollowThrough.Education Funding: Increased K–12 and higher education budgets, including teacher pay raises.
platformFollowThrough.Regulatory Rollback: Eliminated or simplified hundreds of state regulations.
platformFollowThrough.Rural Development: Expanded broadband access and infrastructure investment in underserved counties.

proposals: Further reduce income tax rates, expand school choice, and invest in water infrastructure.
vetoes: Vetoed HB314 (2023), which would have restricted library content access, citing constitutional concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: J.B. Pritzker
bio: J.B. Pritzker is the 43rd Governor of Illinois, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. A businessman and philanthropist, Pritzker has focused his administration on infrastructure investment, education funding, and progressive policy reform.
education: Duke University (BA), Northwestern University School of Law (JD)
endorsements: Illinois Democratic Party, AFL-CIO Illinois, Planned Parenthood Illinois Action
platform: Infrastructure modernization, education equity, healthcare access, and climate action.

platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Modernization: Launched Rebuild Illinois, a $45 billion capital plan for roads, bridges, and public transit.
platformFollowThrough.Education Equity: Increased funding for K–12 and early childhood education, expanded MAP grants for college students.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Access: Expanded Medicaid coverage and launched initiatives to reduce maternal mortality.
platformFollowThrough.Climate Action: Signed the Climate and Equitable Jobs Act to transition Illinois to 100% clean energy by 2050.

proposals: Create a state-level child tax credit, expand paid family leave, and increase funding for behavioral health services.
vetoes: Vetoed HB4091 (2024), which proposed changes to pension fund management, citing fiscal risk.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Mike Braun
bio: Mike Braun is the 52nd Governor of Indiana, elected in 2024 after serving as a U.S. Senator from 2019 to 2025 and a state representative from 2014 to 2017. A businessman and fiscal conservative, Braun has focused his administration on entrepreneurship, utility reform, and workforce development.
education: Wabash College (BA), Harvard Business School (MBA)
endorsements: Indiana Republican Party, National Federation of Independent Business, Indiana Manufacturers Association
platform: Entrepreneurship, utility reform, workforce development, and fiscal discipline.

platformFollowThrough.Entrepreneurship: Launched Power Up Indiana to grow well-paying jobs and support small business innovation.
platformFollowThrough.Utility Reform: Announced initiatives to fight rising utility rates through market-based solutions.
platformFollowThrough.Workforce Development: Prioritized vocational training and partnerships with Indiana manufacturers.
platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Discipline: Committed to reducing state debt and streamlining government operations.

proposals: Cut regulatory red tape, expand apprenticeship programs, and reform state pension liabilities.
vetoes: No vetoes documented as of October 2025.
rankingNote: Not ranked—no verified polling available. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Kim Reynolds
bio: Kim Reynolds is the 43rd Governor of Iowa and the first woman to hold the office. She assumed the role in 2017 after serving as Lieutenant Governor and was elected to full terms in 2018 and 2022. Her administration has focused on tax reform, school choice, and workforce development.
education: Iowa State University (BA in Liberal Studies)
endorsements: Iowa Republican Party, Americans for Prosperity, Iowa Farm Bureau
platform: Tax cuts, school choice, workforce training, and limited government.

platformFollowThrough.Tax Cuts: Signed multiple bills reducing income and corporate tax rates, aiming for a flat tax by 2026.
platformFollowThrough.School Choice: Enacted universal Education Savings Accounts for private school tuition.
platformFollowThrough.Workforce Training: Expanded apprenticeships and launched Future Ready Iowa initiatives.
platformFollowThrough.Limited Government: Streamlined state agencies and reduced regulatory burdens.

proposals: Eliminate income tax entirely, expand parental rights in education, and increase rural broadband funding.
vetoes: Vetoed HF565 (2024), which proposed limits on executive emergency powers, citing constitutional concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Laura Kelly
bio: Laura Kelly is the 48th Governor of Kansas, first elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022. A former state senator and mental health advocate, Kelly has focused her administration on education funding, fiscal stability, and bipartisan governance.
education: University of Missouri (BS), Indiana University (MS in Therapeutic Recreation)
endorsements: Kansas Democratic Party, Kansas National Education Association, American Federation of Teachers Kansas
platform: Education investment, fiscal responsibility, healthcare access, and infrastructure modernization.

platformFollowThrough.Education Investment: Restored funding to public schools and expanded early childhood programs.
platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Responsibility: Balanced budgets and rebuilt the state’s rainy day fund.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Access: Continued push for Medicaid expansion and rural health support.
platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Modernization: Advanced the Eisenhower Legacy Transportation Program for statewide upgrades.

proposals: Expand Medicaid, increase teacher pay, and invest in rural broadband and water infrastructure.
vetoes: Vetoed SB180 (2023), a bill restricting gender identity definitions, citing concerns over discrimination.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Andy Beshear
bio: Andy Beshear is the 63rd Governor of Kentucky, first elected in 2019 and reelected in 2023. A former Attorney General and son of former Governor Steve Beshear, he has focused his administration on disaster recovery, education, infrastructure, and bipartisan governance.
education: Vanderbilt University (BA), University of Virginia School of Law (JD)
endorsements: Kentucky Democratic Party, Kentucky Education Association, United Mine Workers of America
platform: Disaster recovery, education funding, infrastructure investment, and economic development.

platformFollowThrough.Disaster Recovery: Led major flood and tornado recovery efforts with federal and state coordination.
platformFollowThrough.Education Funding: Proposed historic teacher pay raises and expanded preschool access.
platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Investment: Advanced statewide broadband expansion and road upgrades.
platformFollowThrough.Economic Development: Secured record-breaking private investment and job creation across Kentucky.

proposals: Create a permanent disaster relief fund, expand mental health services, and eliminate the state income tax for veterans.
vetoes: Vetoed SB150 (2023), which restricted gender-affirming care for minors, citing medical and civil rights concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Jeff Landry
bio: Jeff Landry is the 57th Governor of Louisiana, elected in 2023 after serving as Attorney General and U.S. Congressman. A former sheriff’s deputy and Marine veteran, Landry has focused his administration on crime reduction, education reform, and conservative governance.
education: University of Louisiana at Lafayette (BS), Loyola University New Orleans (JD)
endorsements: Louisiana Republican Party, National Rifle Association, Louisiana Association of Business and Industry
platform: Crime reduction, school choice, economic growth, and limited government.

platformFollowThrough.Crime Reduction: Launched statewide anti-violence task forces and increased law enforcement funding.
platformFollowThrough.School Choice: Expanded Education Savings Accounts and charter school access.
platformFollowThrough.Economic Growth: Proposed tax incentives for small businesses and energy sector investment.
platformFollowThrough.Limited Government: Issued executive orders to reduce regulatory burdens and consolidate agencies.

proposals: Eliminate personal income tax, expand parental rights in education, and increase rural infrastructure investment.
vetoes: Vetoed SB312 (2024), which proposed new environmental restrictions on energy development.
rankingNote: Tied for rank #21 with McMaster, Polis, and Pritzker. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Janet T. Mills
bio: Janet T. Mills is the 75th Governor of Maine and the first woman to hold the office. First elected in 2018 and reelected in 2022, Mills previously served as Attorney General and a state legislator. Her administration has focused on climate action, education, and healthcare access.
education: University of Massachusetts Boston (BA), University of Maine School of Law (JD)
endorsements: Maine Democratic Party, Maine Education Association, Sierra Club Maine
platform: Climate resilience, education investment, healthcare expansion, and economic development.

platformFollowThrough.Climate Resilience: Launched Maine Won’t Wait climate action plan and invested in offshore wind development.
platformFollowThrough.Education Investment: Expanded pre-K access and increased teacher pay.
platformFollowThrough.Healthcare Expansion: Expanded Medicaid and launched initiatives to address opioid addiction.
platformFollowThrough.Economic Development: Backed small business grants and rural broadband expansion.

proposals: Create a paid family leave program, expand mental health services, and invest in clean energy jobs.

billsSigned.title: Maine Won’t Wait Climate Action Plan (LD99, 2021)

vetoes: Vetoed LD678 (2024), which proposed changes to renewable energy siting rules, citing environmental concerns.
rankingNote: Ranked by polling score. Engagement metrics sourced and verified.

name: Wes Moore
bio: Wes Moore is the 63rd Governor of Maryland and the first Black governor in the state’s history. A combat veteran, author, and former nonprofit CEO, Moore has focused his administration on economic mobility, education, and public safety.
education: Johns Hopkins University (BA), University of Oxford (Rhodes Scholar)
endorsements: Maryland Democratic Party, Maryland State Education Association, Sierra Club Maryland
platform: Economic opportunity, education reform, public safety, and climate action.

platformFollowThrough.Economic Opportunity: Launched the SERVE Act to expand workforce service and job training.
platformFollowThrough.Education Reform: Backed Blueprint for Maryland’s Future to improve funding and outcomes.
platformFollowThrough.Public Safety: Announced statewide crime prevention initiatives and youth intervention programs.
platformFollowThrough.Climate Action: Advanced offshore wind development and clean energy investment.

proposals: Create a child savings account program, expand paid family leave, and increase affordable housing supply.

billsSigned.title: Blueprint for Maryland’s Future Implementation Act (SB1, 2023)

vetoes: Vetoed SB789 (2024), which proposed limits on juvenile justice reform, citing rehabilitation concerns.

name: Maura Healey

endorsements: Massachusetts Democratic Party, Massachusetts Teachers Association, Sierra Club Massachusetts
platform: Affordable housing, climate leadership, education access, and economic opportunity.

proposals: Expand paid family leave, increase mental health funding, and accelerate MBTA modernization.

endorsements: Missouri Republican Party, Missouri Chamber of Commerce, National Rifle Association

name: Jim Pillen
bio: Jim Pillen is the 41st Governor of Nebraska, elected in 2022. A veterinarian, hog producer, and former University of Nebraska regent, Pillen has focused his administration on tax reform, education, and conservative governance.
education: University of Nebraska (BS), Kansas State University (DVM)
endorsements: Nebraska Republican Party, Nebraska Farm Bureau, National Rifle Association
